look_and_say

A python module for exploring look and say sequences in the spirit of John H Conway.

The following assumes familiarity with the terminology and notation for look and sequences introduced by Conway in his delightful article The Weird and Wonderful Chemistry of Audioactive Decay.

This module can be used to recover several of Conway's results on standard look and say sequences. Additionally, it can be used to discover new results on various nonstandard look and say sequences. For an introduction to nonstandard look and say sequences, see the notes here.

Straight to example sessions

You can read more details about all the objects and methods in the look_and_say module below. Here are some example sessions for the reader who wants to jump right into the code.

Standard decimal

The following session illustrates how the look_and_say module can be used to recover some of Conway's results. 

>>> from look_and_say import *
>>> 
>>> # The default LookAndSay object uses the standard decimal number system:
... decimal = LookAndSay()
>>> 
>>> # Perform the fundamental look and say operation:
... decimal.say_what_you_see('1222111')
'113231'
>>> 
>>> # Generate a look and say sequence
... decimal.generate_sequence(seed='1', terms=5)
>>> decimal.get_sequence()
['1', '11', '21', '1211', '111221']
>>> 
>>> # Use Conway's splitting theorem to search for all the elements 
... # in the look and say sequence generated from the seed '1'. 
... # This will generate Conway's 92 common elements: 
... chem = Chemistry(decimal)
>>> chem.generate_elements('1')
>>> chem.get_elements()
[H, He, Li, Be, B, C, N, O, F, Ne, Na, Mg, Al, Si, P, S, Cl, Ar, K, Ca, Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ga, Ge, As, Se, Br, Kr, Rb, Sr, Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd, In, Sn, Sb, Te, I, Xe, Cs, Ba, La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Pm, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu, Hf, Ta, W, Re, Os, Ir, Pt, Au, Hg, Tl, Pb, Bi, Po, At, Rn, Fr, Ra, Ac, Th, Pa, U]
>>> 
>>> # The periodic table is a dictionary holding the chemical properties of each element.
... pt = chem.get_periodic_table(abundance_sum=10**6)
>>> print('Hydrogen:', pt['H'])
Hydrogen: {'string': '22', 'abundance': 91790.383216, 'decay': [H]}
>>> print('Thulium:', pt['Tm'])
Thulium: {'string': '11131221133112', 'abundance': 1204.9083841, 'decay': [Er, Ca, Co]}
>>> 
>>> # Conway's constant can be found as the dominant (i.e. maximal real) eigenvalue of the decay matrix:
... chem.get_dom_eigenvalue()
1.3035772690342982
>>> # Conway's constant is root of the degree 71 factor of the characteristic polynomial:
... chem.get_char_poly()
lambda**18*(lambda - 1)**2*(lambda + 1)*(lambda**71 - lambda**69 - 2*lambda**68 - lambda**67 + 2*lambda**66 + 2*lambda**65 + lambda**64 - lambda**63 - lambda**62 - lambda**61 - lambda**60 - lambda**59 + 2*lambda**58 + 5*lambda**57 + 3*lambda**56 - 2*lambda**55 - 10*lambda**54 - 3*lambda**53 - 2*lambda**52 + 6*lambda**51 + 6*lambda**50 + lambda**49 + 9*lambda**48 - 3*lambda**47 - 7*lambda**46 - 8*lambda**45 - 8*lambda**44 + 10*lambda**43 + 6*lambda**42 + 8*lambda**41 - 5*lambda**40 - 12*lambda**39 + 7*lambda**38 - 7*lambda**37 + 7*lambda**36 + lambda**35 - 3*lambda**34 + 10*lambda**33 + lambda**32 - 6*lambda**31 - 2*lambda**30 - 10*lambda**29 - 3*lambda**28 + 2*lambda**27 + 9*lambda**26 - 3*lambda**25 + 14*lambda**24 - 8*lambda**23 - 7*lambda**21 + 9*lambda**20 + 3*lambda**19 - 4*lambda**18 - 10*lambda**17 - 7*lambda**16 + 12*lambda**15 + 7*lambda**14 + 2*lambda**13 - 12*lambda**12 - 4*lambda**11 - 2*lambda**10 + 5*lambda**9 + lambda**7 - 7*lambda**6 + 7*lambda**5 - 4*lambda**4 + 12*lambda**3 - 6*lambda**2 + 3*lambda - 6)

Gray code

The following session shows how to use the module to explore a nonstandard look and say sequence. We use the binary number system known as Gray code to generate the sequence. The corresponding LookAndSay object depends on the say function which converts a positive integer into its Gray code.

>>> from look_and_say import *
>>>
>>> # Define the "say function"
... def gray(num):
...     '''Returns the binary Gray code of an integer from 1 to 7.'''
...     assert num < 8, "This say function can only count to 7."
...     gray_code = {1:'1', 2:'11', 3:'10', 4:'110', 5:'111', 6:'101', 7:'100'}
...     return gray_code[num]
... 
>>> # Create the LookAndSay object and generate a look and say sequence
... gray_ls = LookAndSay(gray)
>>> gray_ls.generate_sequence(seed='0', terms=6)
>>> gray_ls.get_sequence()
['0', '10', '1110', '10110', '111011110', '10110110110']
>>> 
>>> # Use a BinaryChemistry object to determine the chemical properties
... gray_chem = BinaryChemistry(gray_ls)
>>> gray_chem.generate_elements('0')
>>> gray_chem.print_periodic_table()
element   string   abundance    decay
E1        10       0.0          [E3]
E2        110      58.5786438   [E4]
E3        1110     0.0          [E1, E2]
E4        11110    41.4213562   [E2, E2]
>>> 
>>> # The dominant eigenvalue of the decay matrix gives the long term
... # growth rate of look and say sequences.
... gray_chem.get_dom_eigenvalue()
1.4142135623730958
>>> 
>>> # The growth rate is the maximal real root of the characteristic polynomial
... gray_chem.get_char_poly()
(lambda - 1)*(lambda + 1)*(lambda**2 - 2)

Standard ternary

The following session illustrates how to use the module to explore look and say sequences using the standard ternary number system (i.e. using base 3 with digits 0, 1, and 2). The results are similar to those discussed here.

To construct the corresponding LookAndSay object requires a say function which, in this case, is a function that converts an integer to it's standard ternary representation. The construction of the Chemistry object requires both the LookAndSay object as well as a splitting function which determines when the terms of the look and say sequences split. In this case, one can show that the terms will always split after a run of 0's as well as between a 2 (on the left) and either a 10 or a 1110 (on the right). We use a SplitFuncFactory object to create the splitting function. 

>>> from look_and_say import *
>>> 
>>> # Define a "say function"
... def ternary(num):
...     '''Returns the ternary representation of a nonnegative integer'''
...     if num < 3:
...         return str(num)
...     return ternary(num // 3) + str(num % 3)
...  
>>> # Use the Split Function Factory to create a split function:
... sff = SplitFuncFactory()
>>> sff.declare_split_after('0')
>>> sff.declare_splitting_pairs(('2', '1110'), ('2', '10'))
>>> split = sff.get_split()
>>> 
>>> # Instantiate the LookAndSay and Chemistry objects:
... ternary_ls = LookAndSay(ternary)
>>> ternary_chem = Chemistry(ternary_ls, split)
>>> 
>>> # Generate elements and order them according to relative abundances:
... ternary_chem.generate_elements('0', '1', '2')
>>> ternary_chem.order_elements('abundance')
>>> 
>>> # Print chemical properties:
... ternary_chem.print_periodic_table()
element   string     abundance    decay
E1        10         18.5037375   [E4]
E2        22110      13.9680582   [E5]
E3        2110       13.9680582   [E6]
E4        1110       13.9680582   [E1, E7]
E5        222110     10.5441752   [E1, E2]
E6        122110     10.5441752   [E8]
E7        110        10.5441752   [E3]
E8        11222110   7.9595623    [E3, E2]
E9        222112     0.0          [E1, E10]
E10       22112      0.0          [E9]
E11       212221     0.0          [E16, E4, E13]
E12       2112       0.0          [E14]
E13       211        0.0          [E15]
E14       122112     0.0          [E17]
E15       1221       0.0          [E18]
E16       12         0.0          [E20]
E17       11222112   0.0          [E3, E10]
E18       112211     0.0          [E11]
E19       112        0.0          [E12]
E20       1112       0.0          [E1, E19]
>>>
>>> # Show the dominant eigenvalue which gives the generic growth rate of the look and say sequences.
... print(ternary_chem.get_dom_eigenvalue())
1.3247179572447458
>>> 
>>> # The characteristic polynomial formatted in latex:
... print(ternary_chem.get_char_poly(latex=True))
\lambda^{6} \left(\lambda - 1\right)^{2} \left(\lambda + 1\right)^{2} \left(\lambda^{2} + 1\right) \left(\lambda^{3} - \lambda - 1\right) \left(\lambda^{5} - \lambda^{3} + 1\right)

Look and say sequences

The fundamental class in this module, LookAndSay, is responsible for holding the logic to create look and say sequences. For example, the following shows how to create a standard decimal look and say sequence with 30 terms starting with the seed 555. 

>>> from look_and_say import *
>>> 
>>> # The default LookAndSay object uses the standard decimal number system:
... decimal = LookAndSay()
>>> 
>>> # Generate a look and say sequence
>>> decimal.generate_sequence(seed='555', terms=30)
>>> decimal.get_sequence()

We can extract the ratios of lengths of the terms in the sequence or just the last length ratio:

>>> decimal.get_length_ratios()
[0.6666666666666666, 2.0, 2.0, 1.0, 1.25, 1.8, 1.3333333333333333, 1.1666666666666667, 1.5, 1.3333333333333333, 1.2142857142857142, 1.3529411764705883, 1.3695652173913044, 1.2222222222222223, 1.2857142857142858, 1.3333333333333333, 1.2803030303030303, 1.2958579881656804, 1.3378995433789955, 1.2798634812286689, 1.2853333333333334, 1.329875518672199, 1.2917316692667706, 1.2958937198067633, 1.3131407269338304, 1.304471256210078, 1.294341675734494, 1.3127364438839848, 1.3080371437720142]
>>> decimal.get_last_length_ratio()
1.3080371437720142

The fundamental operation in the LookAndSay class used to compute each term in a look and say sequence is the say_what_you_see() method:

>>> decimal.say_what_you_see('2222')
'42'
>>> decimal.say_what_you_see('2334445555')
'12233445'

By default, when we see a run of four 2's, we say '42'. If we alter the way we say what we see, we get into nonstandard look and say sequences.

Setting up nonstandard look and say sequences with a say function

To start exploring with a nonstandard look and say sequence, the first thing to do is define a say function. The say function will determine how the say-what-you-see operation acts on a run of $n$ consecutive digits $d$, written with Conway's exponent notation as $d^n$. The say function can take one or two parameters:

  • If the say function accepts one parameter, the look and say sequence will correspond to the operation $d^n\to say(n)d$.

  • If the say function accepts two parameters, the look and say sequence will correspond to the operation $d^n\to say(n, d)$.

For example, the following say function can be used to create a Roman numeral look and say sequence.

>>> def roman_say(n):
...     '''Returns the Roman numeral for n assuming 0<n<10'''
...     assert n < 10, "This Roman can only count to 9."
...     roman = {1:'I', 2:'II', 3:'III', 4:'IV', 5:'V', 6:'VI', 7:'VII', 8:'VIII', 9:'IX'}
...     return roman[n]

To get a Roman look and say sequence, pass the say function into the constructor of a LookAndSay object:

>>> roman_ls = LookAndSay(roman_say)
>>> 
>>> roman_ls.generate_sequence('I', 11)
>>> roman_ls.get_sequence()
['I', 'II', 'III', 'IIII', 'IVI', 'IIIVII', 'IIIIIVIII', 'VIIVIIII', 'IVIIIIVIVI', 'IIIVIVIIVIIIVII', 'IIIIIVIIIVIIIIVIIIIIVIII']
>>> 
>>> roman_ls.generate_sequence('V', 11)
>>> roman_ls.get_sequence()
['V', 'IV', 'IIIV', 'IIIIIV', 'VIIV', 'IVIIIIV', 'IIIVIVIIV', 'IIIIIVIIIVIIIIV', 'VIIVIIIIIVIVIIV', 'IVIIIIVVIIVIIIVIIIIV', 'IIIVIVIIIVIIIIVIIIIIVIVIIV']

Standard binary

Here is a standard binary look and say:

>>> def binary_say(num):
...     return "{0:b}".format(num)
... 
>>> binary_ls = LookAndSay(binary_say)
>>> 
>>> binary_ls.generate_sequence('0', 10)
>>> binary_ls.get_sequence()
['0', '10', '1110', '11110', '100110', '1110010110', '111100111010110', '100110011110111010110', '1110010110010011011110111010110', '1111001110101100111001011010011011110111010110']
>>> 
>>> binary_ls.generate_sequence('1', 10)
>>> binary_ls.get_sequence()
['1', '11', '101', '111011', '11110101', '100110111011', '111001011011110101', '111100111010110100110111011', '100110011110111010110111001011011110101', '1110010110010011011110111010110111100111010110100110111011']

The chemistry of the standard binary look and say sequences is determined below.

Two parameter say functions

Here is a look-and-say-again from the paper Stuttering Conway Sequences Are Still Conway Sequences by Brier et al. The say function for this example corresponds to the decay $d^n\to nndd$.

>>> def say_again(n, d):
...     return 2 * str(n) + 2 * d
... 
>>> look_and_say_again = LookAndSay(say_again)
>>> 
>>> look_and_say_again.generate_sequence('1', 11)
>>> look_and_say_again.get_sequence()
['1', '1111', '4411', '22442211', '2222224422222211', '6622224466222211', '226644222244226644222211', '2222226622444422224422222266224444222211', '662222662222444444222244662222662222444444222211', '22664422226644226644442222442266442222664422664444222211', '2222226622444422226622442222226644444422224422222266224444222266224422222266444444222211']
>>> 
>>> look_and_say_again.generate_sequence('2', 11)
>>> look_and_say_again.get_sequence()
['2', '1122', '22112222', '222222114422', '6622221122442222', '226644222211222222444422', '22222266224444222211662244442222', '6622226622224444442222112266222244444422', '226644222266442266444422221122222266442266442222', '222222662244442222662244222222664444442222116622226622442222226622444422', '66222266222244444422226622222244662222666644442222112266442222662222224466222266222244442222']

Here is Morrill's Look Knave:

>>> def knave_say(bit_count, bit):
...     flip = {'0':'1', '1':'0'}
...     return "{0:b}".format(bit_count) + flip[bit]
... 
>>> look_knave = LookAndSay(knave_say)
>>> 
>>> look_knave.generate_sequence('0', 13)
>>> look_knave.get_sequence()
['0', '11', '100', '10101', '1011101110', '10111101111011', '1011100011100011100', '1011110111110111110101', '1011100011101011101011101110', '10111101111101110111101110111101111011', '10111000111010111101110001111011100011100011100', '1011110111110111011100011110111100011110111110111110101', '1011100011101011110111101111000111000111100011101011101011101110']
>>> 
>>> look_knave.generate_sequence('1', 13)
>>> look_knave.get_sequence()
['1', '10', '1011', '1011100', '1011110101', '1011100011101110', '10111101111101111011', '1011100011101011100011100', '1011110111110111011110111110101', '101110001110101111011100011101011101110', '10111101111101110111000111101111101110111101111011', '10111000111010111101111011110001110101111011100011100011100', '10111101111101110111000111000111000111110111011100011110111110111110101']

Chemistry

Generating elements

The terms of standard decimal look and say sequences split into elements according to Conway's Splitting Theorem. Conway's conditions for splitting a string are implemented into the function split_Conway() as illustrated below:

>>> from look_and_say import split_Conway
>>>
>>> split_Conway('1211132213')
['12', '1113', '22', '13']

Given a look and say sequence equipped with a splitting function, a Chemistry object can search for all the elements (i.e. substrings resulting from completely splitting the terms) of the look and say sequence. The default Chemistry object corresponds to standard decimal look and say sequences uses Conway's Splitting Theorem. For example, the following session preforms a search for all elements in the decimal look and say sequence (from above) generated by seed 1. The search yields 92 elements, which agrees with Conway's results:

>>> chem = Chemistry(decimal)
>>> chem.generate_elements('1')
>>> elements = chem.get_elements()
>>> len(elements)
92

Element properties and periodic tables

Each Element is equipped with a name, string, and a decay into other elements. You can get any particular element using its name. You can extract any of the attributes of an element with the appropriate getters as in the following example:

>>> e = chem.get_element('Rh')
>>> e.get_name()
'Rh'
>>> e.get_string()
'311311222113111221131221'
>>> e.get_decay()
[Ho, Ru]

The collection of all the elements and their properties (including their limiting relative abundance in the look and say sequence) is held in the periodic table. You can get the periodic table as a dictionary:

Reordering the elements

The options for the parameter order_on are the following:

  • order_on='abundance': Orders elements from highest abundance to lowest.
  • order_on='string': Orders elements according to the lexicographic order of their strings.
  • order_on='string length': Orders elements according to the lengths of their strings from shortest to longest.
  • order_on='name': Orders elements alphabetically according to their names.
  • order_on='key': Orders elements according to the function specified by the parameter key.

You can reverse the ordering above by passing the extra parameter reverse = True.

By default this method will automatically rename the elements according to their new order. This will not happen if the elements are named via Conway or if the parameter rename = False is passed.

  • A D3 collapsable tree showing the descendants of Methuselum.

  13import numpy
  14import sympy

  16################## Conway's Conventions ############################
  17
  18def split_Conway(string):
  19    """
  20    Splits a string into a list of substrings according to Conway's Splitting Theorem.
  21    Assumes the string is not empty. 
  22
  23    ## Example Session:
  24    ```python
  25    >>> from look_and_say import split_Conway
  26    >>> string = '1211132213'
  27    >>> chunks = split_Conway(string)
  28    >>> print(chunks)
  29    ['12', '1113', '22', '13']
  30
  31    ```
  32    """
  33    chunks = []
  34    start = 0
  35    for i in range(1, len(string)):
  36        if _is_split_pair_Conway(string[start:i], string[i:]):
  37            chunks.append(string[start:i])
  38            start = i
  39    chunks.append(string[start:])
  40    return chunks
  41
  42def _is_split_pair_Conway(L, R):
  43    """Implementation of Conway's Splitting Theorem"""
  44    if L == '' or R == '':
  45            return True # pragma: no cover
  46    if L[-1] not in ['1', '2', '3'] and R[0] in ['1', '2', '3']: # n] and [m
  47            return True
  48    if L[-1] == '2': # 2]
  49            if len(R) > 1 and R[0] == '1' and R[1] != '1' and (len(R) == 2 or R[2] != R[1]): #[1^1X^1
  50                    return True
  51            if len(R) > 2 and R[0] == '1' and R[1] == '1' and R[2] == '1' and (len(R) == 3 or R[3] != '1'): #[1^3
  52                    return True
  53            if R[0] == '3' and (len(R) == 1 or (R[1] != '3' and (len(R) < 4 or R[2] != R[1] or R[3] != R[1]))): #[3^1X^\not=3
  54                    return True
  55            if R[0] not in ['1', '2', '3'] and (len(R) == 1 or R[1] != R[0]): #[n^1
  56                    return True
  57    if L[-1] != '2' and len(R) > 1 and R[0] == '2' and R[1] == '2': # \not=2]
  58            if len(R) > 3 and R[2] == '1' and R[3] != '1' and (len(R) == 4 or R[4] != R[3]): #[2^21^1X^1
  59                    return True
  60            if len(R) > 4 and R[2] == '1' and R[3] == '1' and R[4] == '1' and (len(R) == 5 or R[5] != '1'): #[2^21^3
  61                    return True
  62            if len(R) > 2 and R[2] == '3' and (len(R) == 3 or (R[3] != '3' and (len(R) < 6 or R[4] != R[3] or R[5] != R[3]))): #[2^23^1X^\not=3
  63                    return True 
  64            if len(R) == 2 or (len(R) > 2 and R[2] not in ['1', '2', '3'] and (len(R) == 3 or R[3] != R[2])): #[2^2n^(0 or 1)
  65                    return True
  66    return False
  67

  70def _conway_name(element):
  71    string = element.get_string()
  72    if string in _CONWAY_ELEMENTS:
  73        return _CONWAY_ELEMENTS[string]['name']
  74    Pu = '31221132221222112112322211n'
  75    Np = '1311222113321132211221121332211n'
  76    if len(string) == len(Pu) and string[:-1] == Pu[:-1]:
  77        return 'Pu' + string[-1]
  78    if len(string) == len(Np) and string[:-1] == Np[:-1]:
  79        return 'Np' + string[-1]
  80    return element.get_name()
  81
  82def _conway_number(element):
  83    string = element.get_string()
  84    if string == '':
  85        return 0
  86    elif string in _CONWAY_ELEMENTS:
  87        return _CONWAY_ELEMENTS[string]['number']
  88    else: # Handling transuranic elements
  89        return 92 * int(string[:9]) + ord(string[-1])
  90
  91################# LOOK AND SAY #################################
  92
  93class LookAndSay():
  94    """
  95    A class responsible for the fundamental say-what-you-see operation
  96    that generates a look and say sequence. The parameter ``say`` in the
  97    constructor is a function that determines the decay of a chunk of the form
  98    $a^b$. The say function can have one or two parameters:
  99
 100    * If the say function accepts one parameter, the LookAndSay object will correspond to the decay $a^b\\to say(b)a$.
 101    * If the say function accepts two parameters, the LookAndSay object will correspond to the decay $a^b\\to say(b, a)$.
 102
 103    When no parameter is passed to the constructor, the LookAndSay
 104    object will correspond to standard base ten look and say sequences.
 105
 106    
 107    ## Example Session: Default Constructor. 
 108    The following example uses the default (standard) look and say sequences.
 109    Note that the ratios of lengths are approaching Conway's constant.
 110    ```python 
 111    >>> ls = LookAndSay()  
 112    >>> ls.generate_sequence('55555', 35)
 113    >>> sequence = ls.get_sequence()
 114    >>> first_terms = sequence[:10]
 115    >>> 
 116    >>> print('Sequence:', first_terms)
 117    Sequence: ['55555', '55', '25', '1215', '11121115', '31123115', '132112132115', '11131221121113122115', '311311222112311311222115', '1321132132211213211321322115']
 118    >>> 
 119    >>> print('Ratios of lengths:', ls.get_length_ratios())
 120    Ratios of lengths: [0.4, 1.0, 2.0, 2.0, 1.0, 1.5, 1.6666666666666667, 1.2, 1.1666666666666667, 1.5714285714285714, 1.1818181818181819, 1.1538461538461537, 1.4666666666666666, 1.2727272727272727, 1.25, 1.4, 1.3265306122448979, 1.2461538461538462, 1.3333333333333333, 1.3518518518518519, 1.226027397260274, 1.312849162011173, 1.3361702127659574, 1.2611464968152866, 1.3257575757575757, 1.318095238095238, 1.2919075144508672, 1.3053691275167785, 1.3161953727506426, 1.2936197916666667, 1.2989431303472572, 1.3142192948469587, 1.2951061320754718, 1.2997951286137037]
 121    >>> 
 122    >>> print('Just the last ratio:', ls.get_last_length_ratio())
 123    Just the last ratio: 1.2997951286137037
 124
 125    ```
 126
 127    ## Example Sessions: One parameter say functions
 128
 129    Here is an implementation of a Roman look and say:
 130    ```python
 131    >>> def roman_say(num):
 132    ...     assert num < 10, "This Roman can only count to 9."
 133    ...     roman = {1:'I', 2:'II', 3:'III', 4:'IV', 5:'V', 6:'VI', 7:'VII', 8:'VIII', 9:'IX'}
 134    ...     return roman[num]
 135    ... 
 136    >>> roman_ls = LookAndSay(roman_say)
 137    >>> 
 138    >>> roman_ls.generate_sequence('I', 11)
 139    >>> print(roman_ls.get_sequence())
 140    ['I', 'II', 'III', 'IIII', 'IVI', 'IIIVII', 'IIIIIVIII', 'VIIVIIII', 'IVIIIIVIVI', 'IIIVIVIIVIIIVII', 'IIIIIVIIIVIIIIVIIIIIVIII']
 141    >>> 
 142    >>> roman_ls.generate_sequence('V', 11)
 143    >>> print(roman_ls.get_sequence())
 144    ['V', 'IV', 'IIIV', 'IIIIIV', 'VIIV', 'IVIIIIV', 'IIIVIVIIV', 'IIIIIVIIIVIIIIV', 'VIIVIIIIIVIVIIV', 'IVIIIIVVIIVIIIVIIIIV', 'IIIVIVIIIVIIIIVIIIIIVIVIIV']
 145
 146    ```
 147
 148    Here is a standard binary look and say:
 149    ```python
 150    >>> def binary_say(num):
 151    ...     return "{0:b}".format(num)
 152    ... 
 153    >>> binary_ls = LookAndSay(binary_say)
 154    >>> 
 155    >>> binary_ls.generate_sequence('0', 10)
 156    >>> print(binary_ls.get_sequence())
 157    ['0', '10', '1110', '11110', '100110', '1110010110', '111100111010110', '100110011110111010110', '1110010110010011011110111010110', '1111001110101100111001011010011011110111010110']
 158    >>> 
 159    >>> binary_ls.generate_sequence('1', 10)
 160    >>> print(binary_ls.get_sequence())
 161    ['1', '11', '101', '111011', '11110101', '100110111011', '111001011011110101', '111100111010110100110111011', '100110011110111010110111001011011110101', '1110010110010011011110111010110111100111010110100110111011']
 162
 163    ```
 164    
 165    ## Example Sessions: Two parameter say functions
 166
 167    Here is a *look-and-say-again* from the paper [*Stuttering Conway Sequences Are Still Conway Sequences* by Brier et al](https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.06837).
 168    The say function for this example corresponds to the decay $a^b\\to bbaa$.
 169    ```python
 170    >>> def say_again(char_count, char):
 171    ...     return 2 * str(char_count) + 2 * char
 172    ... 
 173    >>> look_and_say_again = LookAndSay(say_again)
 174    >>> 
 175    >>> look_and_say_again.generate_sequence('1', 11)
 176    >>> print(look_and_say_again.get_sequence())
 177    ['1', '1111', '4411', '22442211', '2222224422222211', '6622224466222211', '226644222244226644222211', '2222226622444422224422222266224444222211', '662222662222444444222244662222662222444444222211', '22664422226644226644442222442266442222664422664444222211', '2222226622444422226622442222226644444422224422222266224444222266224422222266444444222211']
 178    >>> 
 179    >>> look_and_say_again.generate_sequence('2', 11)
 180    >>> print(look_and_say_again.get_sequence())
 181    ['2', '1122', '22112222', '222222114422', '6622221122442222', '226644222211222222444422', '22222266224444222211662244442222', '6622226622224444442222112266222244444422', '226644222266442266444422221122222266442266442222', '222222662244442222662244222222664444442222116622226622442222226622444422', '66222266222244444422226622222244662222666644442222112266442222662222224466222266222244442222']
 182
 183    ```
 184
 185    Here is [Morrill's *Look Knave*](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/bulletin-of-the-australian-mathematical-society/article/abs/look-knave/BFC51822DED97095C96ABD2255AEDC2A):
 186    ```python
 187    >>> def knave_say(bit_count, bit):
 188    ...     flip = {'0':'1', '1':'0'}
 189    ...     return "{0:b}".format(bit_count) + flip[bit]
 190    ... 
 191    >>> look_knave = LookAndSay(knave_say)
 192    >>> 
 193    >>> look_knave.generate_sequence('0', 13)
 194    >>> print(look_knave.get_sequence())
 195    ['0', '11', '100', '10101', '1011101110', '10111101111011', '1011100011100011100', '1011110111110111110101', '1011100011101011101011101110', '10111101111101110111101110111101111011', '10111000111010111101110001111011100011100011100', '1011110111110111011100011110111100011110111110111110101', '1011100011101011110111101111000111000111100011101011101011101110']
 196    >>> 
 197    >>> look_knave.generate_sequence('1', 13)
 198    >>> print(look_knave.get_sequence())
 199    ['1', '10', '1011', '1011100', '1011110101', '1011100011101110', '10111101111101111011', '1011100011101011100011100', '1011110111110111011110111110101', '101110001110101111011100011101011101110', '10111101111101110111000111101111101110111101111011', '10111000111010111101111011110001110101111011100011100011100', '10111101111101110111000111000111000111110111011100011110111110111110101']
 200
 201    ```
 202    """
 203    def __init__(self, say = None):
 204        super(LookAndSay, self).__init__()
 205        self._is_Conway = False
 206        if say == None:
 207            say = (lambda n : str(n))
 208            self._is_Conway = True
 209        self.say = say
 210        self.sequence = []
 211
 212    def _chunk_op(self, char_count, char):
 213        """
 214        Conversion of the say function to a two parameter function 
 215        if the say function takes only one parameter; 
 216        just a copy of the say function otherwise.
 217        """
 218        try:
 219            return self.say(char_count, char)
 220        except:
 221            return self.say(char_count) + char
 222
 223    def get_sequence(self):
 224        """Returns the look and say sequence as a list of strings"""
 225        return self.sequence
 226
 227    def say_what_you_see(self, string):
 228        """
 229        The fundamental look and say operation that generates each 
 230        term of a look and say sequence from its predecessor. For example, 
 231        using the standard (default) LookAndSay object, 
 232        ``say_what_you_see('1112222333')`` returns ``'314233'``.
 233        """
 234        if not string: return '' # handles empty string, which is falsy
 235        letter = string[0]
 236        result = ''
 237        count = 0
 238        for ch in string:
 239            if ch == letter: 
 240                count += 1
 241            else:
 242                result += self._chunk_op(count, letter)
 243                count = 1
 244                letter = ch 
 245        result += self._chunk_op(count, letter)
 246        return result
 247     
 248    def generate_sequence(self, seed, terms):
 249        """
 250        Generates the look and say sequence. The parameter ``seed`` is 
 251        the initial term in the sequence, and ``terms`` is the 
 252        number of terms generated.
 253        """
 254        if not seed: return None # handles empty seed, which is falsy
 255        result = [seed]
 256        for _ in range(terms-1):
 257            result.append(self.say_what_you_see(result[-1]))
 258        self.sequence = result
 259
 260    def get_length_ratios(self):
 261        """
 262        Returns a list of the ratios of lengths of 
 263        successive terms in the look and say sequence.
 264        """
 265        terms = len(self.sequence)
 266        assert terms > 1, 'Look and say sequence does not have enough terms to compute the ratio of lengths.'
 267        return [len(self.sequence[i+1]) / len(self.sequence[i]) for i in range(terms - 1)]
 268
 269    def get_last_length_ratio(self):
 270        """
 271        Returns the ratio of the lengths of the last 
 272        two terms of the look and say sequence
 273        """
 274        return self.get_length_ratios()[-1]
 275
 276
 277
 278########### CHEMISTRY #####################
 279
 280class Chemistry():
 281    """
 282    A class responsible for generating all the persistent elements 
 283    appearing in look and say sequences, along with 
 284    the chemical properties of those elements.
 285
 286    Parameters in the constructor are a LookAndSay object ``las`` and
 287    a splitting function ``split``. The user is responsible
 288    for verifying that the provided splitting function is valid for the given
 289    LookAndSay object. The default splitting function corresponds to 
 290    Conway's original Splitting Theorem.
 291

 514    ## Example Session: Standard Ternary
 515
 516    ```python
 517    >>> # Define the say function:
 518    ... def ternary(num):
 519    ...     if num < 3:
 520    ...         return str(num)
 521    ...     return ternary(num // 3) + str(num % 3)
 522    ... 
 523    >>> 
 524    >>> # Use the Split Function Factory to create a split function:
 525    ... sff = SplitFuncFactory()
 526    >>> sff.declare_split_after('0')
 527    >>> sff.declare_splitting_pairs(('2', '1110'), ('2', '10'))
 528    >>> split = sff.get_split()
 529    >>> 
 530    >>> # Instantiate the LookAndSay and Chemistry objects:
 531    ... ternary_ls = LookAndSay(ternary)
 532    >>> ternary_chem = Chemistry(ternary_ls, split)
 533    >>> 
 534    >>> # Generate elements and order them according to relative abundances:
 535    ... ternary_chem.generate_elements('0', '1', '2')
 536    >>> ternary_chem.order_elements('abundance')
 537    >>> 
 538    >>> # Print chemical properties:
 539    ... ternary_chem.print_periodic_table()
 540    element   string     abundance    decay
 541    E1        10         18.5037375   [E4]
 542    E2        22110      13.9680582   [E5]
 543    E3        2110       13.9680582   [E6]
 544    E4        1110       13.9680582   [E1, E7]
 545    E5        222110     10.5441752   [E1, E2]
 546    E6        122110     10.5441752   [E8]
 547    E7        110        10.5441752   [E3]
 548    E8        11222110   7.9595623    [E3, E2]
 549    E9        222112     0.0          [E1, E10]
 550    E10       22112      0.0          [E9]
 551    E11       212221     0.0          [E16, E4, E13]
 552    E12       2112       0.0          [E14]
 553    E13       211        0.0          [E15]
 554    E14       122112     0.0          [E17]
 555    E15       1221       0.0          [E18]
 556    E16       12         0.0          [E20]
 557    E17       11222112   0.0          [E3, E10]
 558    E18       112211     0.0          [E11]
 559    E19       112        0.0          [E12]
 560    E20       1112       0.0          [E1, E19]
 561    >>> 
 562    >>> print(ternary_chem.get_char_poly())
 563    lambda**6*(lambda - 1)**2*(lambda + 1)**2*(lambda**2 + 1)*(lambda**3 - lambda - 1)*(lambda**5 - lambda**3 + 1)
 564    >>> 
 565    >>> print(ternary_chem.get_dom_eigenvalue())
 566    1.3247179572447458
 567
 568    ```
 569
 570    
 571    ## Example Session: Balanced Ternary
 572    In this example we find the chemical properties of a [balanced ternary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balanced_ternary)
 573    look and say sequence. 
 574
 575    ```python
 576    >>> # Define a (partial) say function to convert integers to balanced ternary:
 577    ... def bal_tern(num):
 578    ...     assert num < 11, "bal_tern will only convert integers from 1 to 10."
 579    ...     repn = {1:'1', 2:'1T', 3:'10', 4:'11', 5:'1TT', 6:'1T0', 7:'1T1', 8:'10T', 9:'100', 10:'101'}
 580    ...     return repn[num]
 581    ... 
 582    >>> # Use the split function factory to generate an appropriate split function: 
 583    ... sff = SplitFuncFactory()
 584    >>> sff.declare_split_after('0', 'T')
 585    >>> split = sff.get_split()
 586    >>> 
 587    >>> # Instantiate the look and say and chemistry objects:
 588    ... bal_tern_ls = LookAndSay(bal_tern)
 589    >>> bal_tern_chem = Chemistry(bal_tern_ls, split)
 590    >>> 
 591    >>> # Generate persistent elements from the seed '0', and order them according to their relative abundance:
 592    ... bal_tern_chem.generate_elements('0')
 593    >>> bal_tern_chem.order_elements('abundance')
 594    >>> 
 595    >>> # Print the chemical properties
 596    ... bal_tern_chem.print_periodic_table()
 597    element   string   abundance    decay
 598    E1        1T       23.6067977   [E3]
 599    E2        11T      23.6067977   [E1, E2]
 600    E3        111T     14.5898034   [E5, E2]
 601    E4        110      14.5898034   [E1, E4]
 602    E5        10       14.5898034   [E6]
 603    E6        1110     9.0169944    [E5, E4]
 604    >>> 
 605    >>> print(bal_tern_chem.get_char_poly())
 606    lambda**3*(lambda - 1)*(lambda**2 - lambda - 1)
 607    >>> 
 608    >>> print(bal_tern_chem.get_dom_eigenvalue()) # golden!
 609    1.6180339887498958
 610
 611    ```
 612    """
 613    def __init__(self, las, split = split_Conway, elements = None):
 614        super(Chemistry, self).__init__()
 615        self.las = las
 616        self.split = split
 617        if elements == None:
 618            elements = []
 619        self.elements = elements
 620
 621    def get_elements(self):
 622        """Returns the elements as a list."""
 623        return self.elements
 624
 625    def get_element(self, name):
 626        """Returns the element with the given name. Returns None there is no element with the given name."""
 627        for e in self.elements:
 628            if e.get_name() == name:
 629                return e
 630
 631    def clear_elements(self):
 632        """Resets the list of elements back to the empty list."""
 633        self.elements = []
 634
 635    def _split_to_elements(self, string): 
 636        return [Element(chunk, self.las) for chunk in self.split(string)]
 637
 638    def _generate_all_elements(self, strings):
 639        for string in strings:
 640            for elt in self._split_to_elements(string):
 641                if elt not in self.elements:
 642                    # add elt to the chemistry:
 643                    self.elements.append(elt)
 644                    # recursively set the decay for elt:
 645                    decay_elts = self._split_to_elements(self.las.say_what_you_see(elt.get_string()))
 646                    self._generate_all_elements(map(lambda e : e.get_string(), decay_elts))
 647                    elt._set_decay(decay_elts)
 648        # clean up decay for all elements:
 649        for elt in self.elements:
 650            dec = []
 651            for d in elt.get_decay():
 652                dec += [e for e in self.elements if e == d]
 653            elt._set_decay(dec)
 654
 655    def _remove_intermittent_elements(self): 
 656        while True:
 657            common_elements = []
 658            for elt in self.elements:
 659                for d in elt.get_decay():
 660                    if d not in common_elements:
 661                        common_elements.append(d)
 662            if len(common_elements) < len(self.elements):
 663                self.elements = list(common_elements)
 664            else: 
 665                break # pragma: no cover
 666
 667    def generate_elements(self, *seeds, reset = True):
 668        """
 669        Collects all the persistent elements from all the look and
 670        say sequences generated by the given seeds. The string(s) entered as the 
 671        parameter(s) will be used as the seed(s) for generating the elements. 
 672        By default, this method will clear any elements in the chemistry that exist 
 673        before this method is called (i.e. prior to collecting from the new seeds). 
 674        Use ``reset = False``  to keep the old elements. 
 675        """
 676        if reset:
 677            self.clear_elements()
 678        strings = [self.las.say_what_you_see(seed) for seed in seeds] #only look at 2-day-old strings
 679        self._generate_all_elements(strings)
 680        self._remove_intermittent_elements()
 681        if reset:
 682            self.order_elements('string')
 683        self._name_elements()
 684
 685    def _name_elements(self):
 686        if self.las._is_Conway:
 687            for e in self.get_elements():
 688                e.set_name(_conway_name(e))
 689            self.elements = sorted(self.get_elements(), key = _conway_number)
 690        else:
 691            for i, e in enumerate(self.get_elements()):
 692                e.set_name('E' + str(i + 1))
 693
 694    def get_decay_matrix(self):
 695        """
 696        Returns the decay matrix as a nested list of integers 
 697        (i.e. a list of the rows).
 698        The order of the columns and rows correspond to the order
 699        in the list of elements.
 700        """
 701        mat = []
 702        e = self.elements
 703        for i in range(len(e)):
 704            row = []
 705            for j in range(len(e)):
 706                row.append(e[j].get_decay().count(e[i]))
 707            mat.append(row)
 708        return mat
 709
 710    def get_dom_eigenvalue(self):
 711        """
 712        Returns the maximal real eigenvalue of the decay matrix.
 713        In the standard case, this will give Conway's constant. 
 714        In general, this will give the growth rate of the look and say sequence. 
 715        This method assumes the existence of a real eigenvalue which
 716        is larger than (the absolute value) of every other eigenvalue.
 717        This assumption is usually guaranteed by the Perron-Frobenius Theorem.
 718        """
 719        assert len(self.elements) > 0, "The get_dom_eigenvalue method requires a nonempty list of elements.\n\tTo fix: Use the generate_elements method prior to calling get_dom_eigenvalue."
 720        eigenstuff = numpy.linalg.eig(numpy.array(self.get_decay_matrix()))
 721        eigenvalues = eigenstuff[0]
 722        return max(eigenvalues).real
 723
 724    def get_char_poly(self, factor = True, latex = False):
 725        """
 726        Returns the characteristic polynomial of the decay matrix using sympy.
 727        By default the returned polynomial will be factored. 
 728        Use ``factor = False`` to get the expanded (i.e. unfactored) polynomial. 
 729        Use ``latex = True`` to return the polynomial formatted in latex.
 730        """
 731        chi = sympy.Matrix(self.get_decay_matrix()).charpoly()
 732        if factor:
 733            chi = sympy.factor(chi.as_expr())
 734        else:
 735            chi = chi.as_expr()
 736        if latex:
 737            return sympy.latex(chi)
 738        else:
 739            return chi
 740
 741    def _get_abundances(self, dec_places = 7, abundance_sum = 100):
 742        """
 743        Returns a list of relative abundances of each element.
 744        By default the abundances are given as percentages, 
 745        so they will differ from Conway's abundances by a factor of $10^4$.
 746        The abundances can be renormalized by setting the parameter ``abundance_sum``.
 747        The order of the list corresponds to the order of the list of elements.
 748        """
 749        eigenstuff = numpy.linalg.eig(numpy.array(self.get_decay_matrix()))
 750        eigenvalues = eigenstuff[0]
 751        eigenvectors = eigenstuff[1]
 752        index = numpy.where(eigenvalues == max(eigenvalues))
 753        limiting_eigenvector_nparray = eigenvectors[:,index].real
 754        # The next two lines are converting the numpy array to a list
 755        limiting_eigenvector = limiting_eigenvector_nparray.tolist()
 756        limiting_eigenvector = [elt[0][0] for elt in limiting_eigenvector]
 757        abundance = [abs(round(abundance_sum * num / sum(limiting_eigenvector), dec_places)) for num in limiting_eigenvector]
 758        return abundance
 759

 777                                'abundance' : self._get_abundances(dec_places, abundance_sum)[i],
 778                                'decay' : e.get_decay()}
 779                                for i, e in enumerate(self.get_elements())}
 780
 781    def print_periodic_table(self, dec_places = 7, abundance_sum = 100):
 782        """
 783        Prints the periodic table. Note the abundances are given as percentages, 
 784        so they will differ from Conway's abundances by a factor of $10^4$.
 785        The parameter ``dec_places`` refers to the accuracy of the abundances.
 786        """
 787        pt = self.get_periodic_table(dec_places, abundance_sum)
 788        elt_width = 2 + max(len('element'), max([len(e.get_name()) for e in self.get_elements()]))
 789        str_width = 2 + max(len('string'), max([len(e.get_string()) for e in self.get_elements()]))
 790        ab_width  = 2 + max(len('abundance'), max([len(str(prop['abundance'])) for elt, prop in pt.items()]))
 791        print("{:<{elt_width}} {:<{str_width}} {:<{ab_width}} {}".format('element', 'string', 'abundance', 'decay', elt_width=elt_width, str_width=str_width, ab_width=ab_width))
 792        for elt, prop in pt.items():
 793            print("{:<{elt_width}} {:<{str_width}} {:<{ab_width}} {}".format(elt, prop['string'], prop['abundance'], str(prop['decay']), elt_width=elt_width, str_width=str_width, ab_width=ab_width))
 794
 795    def order_elements(self, order_on, key = None, reverse = False, rename = True):
 796        """
 797        Reorders the list of elements depending on the parameter ``order_on`` as follows:
 798
 799        * ``order_on='abundance'``: Orders elements from highest abundance to lowest.
 800        * ``order_on='string'``: Orders elements according to the lexicographic order of their strings.
 801        * ``order_on='string length'``: Orders elements according to the lengths of their strings from shortest to longest.
 802        * ``order_on='name'``: Orders elements alphabetically according to their names.
 803        * ``order_on='key'``: Orders elements according to the function specified by the parameter ``key``.
 804
 805        You can reverse the ordering above by passing the extra parameter ``reverse = True``.
 806        
 807        By default this method will automatically rename the elements according to their new order.
 808        This will not happen if the elements are named via Conway or if the parameter ``rename = False`` is passed.
 809        """
 810        assert order_on in ['abundance', 'name', 'string', 'string length', 'key'], "Invalid parameter passed to order_elements. Valid parameter are 'abundance', 'name', 'string', 'string length', and 'key'."
 811        pt = self.get_periodic_table()
 812        sorted_key = {
 813            'abundance': lambda e : pt[e.get_name()]['abundance'],
 814            'name': lambda e : e.get_name(),
 815            'string': lambda e : e.get_string(),
 816            'string length': lambda e : len(e.get_string()),
 817            'key': key
 818        }
 819        self.elements = sorted(self.get_elements(), key = sorted_key[order_on])
 820        if order_on == 'abundance':
 821            self.elements.reverse()
 822        if reverse:
 823            self.elements.reverse()
 824        if not self.las._is_Conway and rename:
 825            self._name_elements()
 826
 827class BinaryChemistry(Chemistry):
 828    """
 829    A chemistry for binary look and say sequences that split as 1.0 
 830    (i.e. whenever a 1 is left of a 0). This chemistry is valid whenever
 831    the say-what-you-see operation maps 
 832    $a^b$ to $[b]a$ where $[b]$ is a binary
 833    string that always starts with a 1. For example, this chemistry is 
 834    valid for standard base two binary look and say sequences. 
 835
 836    ## Example Session: Standard Binary
 837
 838    ```python
 839    >>> def binary_say(num):
 840    ...     return "{0:b}".format(num)
 841    ... 
 842    >>> binary_ls = LookAndSay(binary_say)
 843    >>> binary_chem = BinaryChemistry(binary_ls)
 844    >>> binary_chem.generate_elements('1')
 845    >>> binary_chem.order_elements('abundance')
 846    >>> binary_chem.print_periodic_table()
 847    element   string   abundance    decay
 848    E1        110      21.6756572   [E2, E1]
 849    E2        10       21.6756572   [E3]
 850    E3        1110     14.7899036   [E4]
 851    E4        11110    10.0915624   [E6, E1]
 852    E5        1100     10.0915624   [E2, E5]
 853    E6        100      10.0915624   [E7]
 854    E7        11100    6.8857536    [E8]
 855    E8        111100   4.6983411    [E6, E5]
 856    E9        11       0.0          [E2, E10]
 857    E10       1        0.0          [E9]
 858    >>>
 859    >>> print(binary_chem.get_dom_eigenvalue())
 860    1.4655712318767664
 861
 862    ```
 863
 864    ## Example Session: Twindragon Binary
 865    The following chemistry corresponds to the binary number system using 
 866    the complex base $-1+i.$ This binary number system is known as *twindragon binary*.
 867
 868    ```python
 869    >>> def twindragon_say(num):
 870    ...     assert num < 8, "This twindragon can only count to 7."
 871    ...     twindragon = {1:'1', 2:'1100', 3:'1101', 4:'111010000', 5:'111010001', 6:'111011100', 7:'111011101'}
 872    ...     return twindragon[num]
 873    ... 
 874    >>> twindragon_ls = LookAndSay(twindragon_say)
 875    >>> twindragon_chem = BinaryChemistry(twindragon_ls)
 876    >>> twindragon_chem.generate_elements('1')
 877    >>> twindragon_chem.print_periodic_table()
 878    element   string   abundance    decay
 879    E1        1        0.0          [E6]
 880    E2        10       6.746022     [E9]
 881    E3        1000     1.5358344    [E11, E2]
 882    E4        10000    2.8580442    [E12, E5]
 883    E5        100000   1.3339664    [E12, E3, E2]
 884    E6        11       0.0          [E8, E1]
 885    E7        110      28.3551578   [E8, E7]
 886    E8        1100     24.8181731   [E8, E10]
 887    E9        1110     14.6891551   [E7, E9]
 888    E10       111000   11.5836587   [E7, E11, E2]
 889    E11       11110    6.1234052    [E9, E4, E7]
 890    E12       111110   1.9565832    [E9, E3, E9]
 891
 892    ```
 893    """
 894    def __init__(self, las, elements = None):
 895        sff = SplitFuncFactory()
 896        sff.declare_split_before('1')
 897        binary_split = sff.get_split()
 898        super().__init__(las, binary_split, elements)

 900########### ELEMENT #######################
 901
 902class Element():
 903    """
 904    An element consists of a string (usually a chunk of digits) and 
 905    a name. For example, in Conway's chemistry there is an element
 906    named H (short for Hydrogen) consisting of the string '22'. 
 907    Each element decays into a list of other elements. 
 908    The only methods for this class are getters and a setter.
 909    """
 910    def __init__(self, string, las, decay = []):
 911        super(Element, self).__init__()
 912        self.string = string
 913        self.las = las
 914        self.name = string
 915        self.decay = decay
 916
 917    def __str__(self):
 918        return self.name
 919
 920    def __repr__(self):
 921        return self.name
 922
 923    def __eq__(self, other):
 924        """Overrides the default implementation"""
 925        if isinstance(other, Element):
 926                return self.string == other.string and self.las == other.las
 927        return NotImplemented
 928
 929    def __hash__(self):
 930        """Overrides the default implementation"""
 931        return hash((self.string, self.las))
 932
 933    def _set_decay(self, elements):
 934        self.decay = elements
 935
 936    def get_decay(self):
 937        return self.decay
 938
 939    def set_name(self, name):
 940        self.name = name
 941
 942    def get_name(self):
 943        return self.name
 944
 945    def get_string(self):
 946        return self.string
 947
 948########### SPLIT FUNCTION FACTORY #####################
 949
 950class SplitFuncFactory():
 951    """
 952    A class to help create a split function. The split function factory
 953    can produce a split function via any combination of the following:
 954
 955    * Specifying specific chunks L and R such that LR splits as L.R.
 956    * Specifying specific characters or chunks to always split before or after.
 957
 958    ## Example Session: Split after 0
 959    Many look and say sequences split after any run of 0's. 
 960    The following illustrates how the split function factory can 
 961    be used to create such a split function:
 962    ```python
 963    >>> sff = SplitFuncFactory()
 964    >>> sff.declare_split_after('0')
 965    >>> split = sff.get_split()
 966    >>> string = '1101230022200012301325023'
 967    >>> print(split(string))
 968    ['110', '12300', '222000', '1230', '13250', '23']
 969
 970    ```
 971
 972
 973    ## Example Session: A combination of multiple methods.
 974    ```python
 975    >>> sff = SplitFuncFactory()
 976    >>> sff.declare_split_before('111')
 977    >>> sff.declare_split_after('2', '30')
 978    >>> sff.declare_splitting_pairs(('11', '333'))
 979    >>> split = sff.get_split()
 980    >>> string = '1234411154211333234530411113333344'
 981    >>> print(split(string))
 982    ['12', '344', '111542', '11', '3332', '34530', '4', '1111', '3333344']
 983
 984    ```
 985    """
 986    def __init__(self):
 987        self._splitting_pairs = []
 988        self._chunks_before_split = []
 989        self._chunks_after_split = []
 990
 991    def get_split(self):
 992        """Returns the split function."""
 993        return lambda string : self._split(string)
 994
 995    def _split(self, string):
 996        chunks = []
 997        start = 0
 998        for i in range(1, len(string)):
 999            if self._is_split(string[start:i], string[i:]):
1000                chunks.append(string[start:i])
1001                start = i
1002        chunks.append(string[start:])
1003        return chunks
1004
1005    def _is_split(self, L, R):
1006        if L == '' or R == '':
1007            return True # pragma: no cover
1008        if L[-1] == R[0]:
1009            return False
1010        for l in self._chunks_before_split:
1011            if len(l) <= len(L) and l == L[-len(l):]:
1012                return True
1013        for r in self._chunks_after_split:
1014            if len(r) <= len(R) and r == R[:len(r)]:
1015                return True
1016        for l, r in self._splitting_pairs:
1017            if len(l) <= len(L) and len(r) <= len(R) and l == L[-len(l):] and r == R[:len(r)]:
1018                return True
1019        return False
1020
1021    def declare_splitting_pairs(self, *pairs):
1022        """
1023        Specify pairs of chunks in the form (L, R) 
1024        such that LR always splits as L.R.
1025
1026        ## Example Session:
1027        ```python
1028        >>> sff = SplitFuncFactory()
1029        >>> sff.declare_splitting_pairs(('311', '223'), ('0', '1'))
1030        >>> split = sff.get_split()
1031        >>> string = '12311223323112011200011110234234'
1032        >>> print(split(string))
1033        ['12311', '2233231120', '112000', '11110234234']
1034
1035        ```
1036        """
1037        for pair in pairs:
1038            self._splitting_pairs.append(pair)
1039
1040    def declare_split_after(self, *chunks):
1041        """
1042        Specify chunks L such that LR splits for every possible R (assuming the last character of L and the first character of R are distinct).
1043        
1044        ## Example Session:
1045        ```python
1046        >>> sff = SplitFuncFactory()
1047        >>> sff.declare_split_after('1', '20')
1048        >>> split = sff.get_split()
1049        >>> string = '12311223323112011200011110234234'
1050        >>> print(split(string))
1051        ['1', '2311', '22332311', '20', '11', '20001111', '0234234']
1052
1053        ```
1054        """
1055        for chunk in chunks:
1056            self._chunks_before_split.append(chunk)
1057
1058    def declare_split_before(self, *chunks):
1059        """Specify chunks R such that LR splits for every possible L (assuming the last character of L and the first character of R are distinct).
1060
1061        ## Example Session:
1062        ```python
1063        >>> sff = SplitFuncFactory()
1064        >>> sff.declare_split_before('0', '31')
1065        >>> split = sff.get_split()
1066        >>> string = '12311223323112011200011110234234'
1067        >>> print(split(string))
1068        ['12', '31122332', '3112', '0112', '0001111', '0234234']
1069
1070        ```
1071        """
1072        for chunk in chunks:
1073            self._chunks_after_split.append(chunk)
1074
1075########### COSMOLOGY #####################
1076
1077class Cosmology():
1078    '''
1079    A class for proving Conway's Cosmological Theorem.
1080    Currently this will only prove The Cosmological Theorem 
1081    for the standard base ten look and say sequences where every term
1082    consists of strings of some of the digits 1, 2, and 3.  
1083    '''
1084    def __init__(self, digits = '123'):
1085        self.look_and_say = LookAndSay()
1086        self.split = split_Conway
1087        self.digits = digits
1088        self._compendium_sets = []
1089        self.common_strings = {elt for elt in _CONWAY_ELEMENTS}
1090        # add transuranic elements to the list of common strings:
1091        for digit in self.digits:
1092            if digit not in '123':
1093                self.common_strings.add('31221132221222112112322211' + digit)
1094                self.common_strings.add('1311222113321132211221121332211' + digit)
1095
1096    def days_exotic(self, string):
1097        '''
1098        Returns the number of days until the string splits into a compound of common elements. 
1099        '''
1100        atoms = [atom for atom in self.split(string) if atom not in self.common_strings]
1101        days = 0
1102        while atoms != []:
1103            next_atoms = []
1104            for atom in atoms:
1105                new_atoms = self.split(self.look_and_say.say_what_you_see(atom))
1106                next_atoms += [a for a in new_atoms if a not in self.common_strings]
1107            atoms = next_atoms
1108            days += 1
1109        return days
1110
1111    def decay_tree(self, string):
1112        '''
1113        Starting with the passed string, the say_what_you_see operation is applied
1114        repeatedly until the result splits as a compound of common elements. 
1115        Returns a nested dictionary corresponding to the resulting *decay tree*: 
1116        The root of the tree is the passed string, the children of a node are the 
1117        atoms obtained by applying the say_what_you_see operation to the node and 
1118        splitting the result, the leaves are the nodes corresponding to common elements.
1119        '''
1120        if string in self.common_strings:
1121            return string
1122        return {string: [self.decay_tree(atom) for atom in self.split(self.look_and_say.say_what_you_see(string))]}
1123
1124
1125    def proof(self, day = 9):
1126        '''
1127        Uses a backtracking algorithm to prove Conway's Cosmological Theorem. If we pass the parameter
1128        ``day = N`` the algorithm searches for all strings that might appear as chunks of an N-day
1129        old element. The search starts with strings of length 1 (i.e. the digits) and then 
1130        searches for strings of length 2, then length 3, etc. For each string found in the search, 
1131        the algorithm repeatedly applies the say-what-you-see operation until the result is a 
1132        compound of common elements. The algorithm terminates when for some positive integer L, 
1133        there are no strings of length L that can appear as chunks of an N-day old element, and 
1134        all strings of length less than L which might appear as a chunk of an N-day old element 
1135        are shown to eventually decay into a compound of common elements.
1136
1137        Running the program prints a few details about the search. In particular, an upper bound
1138        for the age of an exotic (i.e. not common) element is displayed.  
1139
1140        The default parameter is ``day = 9``, which results in a proof of the Cosmological Theorem
1141        that gives an upper bound of 27 for the age of an exotic element. 
1142
1143        The proof is essentially the same as that of Zeilberger. 
1144        The implementation is similar to that of Litherland.
1145        '''
1146        chunks = self.digits # start with length 1 chunks
1147        max_days_exotic = 0
1148
1149        print(f'To prove the Cosmological Theorem we search for all strings\nwhich could appear as chunks of {day} day old elements.\nSearching...')
1150        length = 0
1151        while True:
1152            length += 1
1153            compendium = []
1154            #Gather all chunks that have a grandparent to the compendium
1155            for chunk in chunks:
1156                if self._has_grandparent(chunk, day):
1157                    compendium.append(chunk)
1158
1159            if compendium == []:
1160                print(f'There are no strings of length {length} that can appear as chunks\nof {day} day old elements. All strings of length less than {length}\nthat could appear after {day} days decay into compounds of common\nelements after an additional {max_days_exotic-day} days. This gives an upper\nbound of {max_days_exotic} days for the age of an exotic element.\nQ.E.D.')
1161                return max_days_exotic
1162
1163            self._compendium_sets.append(set(compendium))
1164
1165            #Compute an upper bound on the maximum longevity of an exotic element:
1166            for chunk in compendium:
1167                lifespan = day + self.days_exotic(chunk)
1168                if lifespan > max_days_exotic:
1169                    max_days_exotic = lifespan
1170
1171            chunks = []
1172            #For each found above, add all possible digits to the left and check if splits
1173            for digit in self.digits:
1174                chunks += [digit+chunk for chunk in compendium if len(self.split(digit+chunk)) == 1]
1175
1176    def _parents(self, kid):
1177        '''
1178        We call a string a *parent* of the kid if applying the say-what-you-see operation
1179        results in a string which contains the kid as a substring. This function returns
1180        a list of all the minimal parents of kid (here minimal means that every parent of
1181        the kid will contain one of the elements of the list as a substring).
1182        '''
1183        parents = []
1184        if self._is_day_one_even(kid):
1185            parents += self._even_parents(kid)
1186        if self._is_day_one_odd(kid):
1187            parents += self._odd_parents(kid)
1188        return parents
1189
1190    def _is_day_one_odd(self, string):
1191        if len(string) == 1:
1192            return False
1193        if len(string) % 2 == 0:
1194            i = 0
1195        else:
1196            i = 1
1197        while i < len(string) - 2:
1198            if string[i] == string[i+2]:
1199                return False
1200            i += 2
1201        return True
1202
1203    def _is_day_one_even(self, string):
1204        if len(string) == 1:
1205            return True
1206        if len(string) % 2 == 0:
1207            i = 1
1208        else:
1209            i = 0
1210        while i < len(string) - 2:
1211            if string[i] == string[i+2]:
1212                return False
1213            i += 2
1214        return True
1215
1216    def _even_parents(self, string):
1217        new_string = ''
1218        if len(string) % 2 == 0:
1219            start = 0
1220        else:
1221            start = 1
1222            new_string += string[0]
1223        while start < len(string) - 1:
1224            new_string += int(string[start]) * string[start+1]
1225            start += 2
1226        return [new_string]
1227
1228    def _odd_parents(self, string):
1229        new_string = ''
1230        if len(string) % 2 == 0:
1231            start = 1
1232            new_string += string[0]
1233        else:
1234            start = 0
1235        while start < len(string) - 2:
1236            new_string += int(string[start]) * string[start+1]
1237            start += 2
1238        return [new_string + int(string[-1]) * digit for digit in self.digits if digit != string[-2]]
1239
1240
1241    def _has_grandparent(self, kid, day):
1242        '''
1243        Returns True if the string kid *might* be contained in the result of applying
1244        the say-what-you-see operation day-times to some string. Note that this method
1245        will only return False when kid cannot be part of a day-old descendant of 
1246        any string, but may return True even if kid is not contained in any day-old descendant.
1247        '''
1248        # Apply the parents function day-times and see what we get:
1249        ancestors = [kid]
1250        for _ in range(day):
1251            next_ancestors = []
1252            for a in ancestors:
1253                next_ancestors += self._parents(a)
1254            ancestors = next_ancestors
1255
1256        return len(ancestors) != 0
def split_Conway(string) 
19def split_Conway(string):
20    """
21    Splits a string into a list of substrings according to Conway's Splitting Theorem.
22    Assumes the string is not empty. 
23
24    ## Example Session:
25    ```python
26    >>> from look_and_say import split_Conway
27    >>> string = '1211132213'
28    >>> chunks = split_Conway(string)
29    >>> print(chunks)
30    ['12', '1113', '22', '13']
31
32    ```
33    """
34    chunks = []
35    start = 0
36    for i in range(1, len(string)):
37        if _is_split_pair_Conway(string[start:i], string[i:]):
38            chunks.append(string[start:i])
39            start = i
40    chunks.append(string[start:])
41    return chunks

class LookAndSay: 
 94class LookAndSay():
 95    """
 96    A class responsible for the fundamental say-what-you-see operation
 97    that generates a look and say sequence. The parameter ``say`` in the
 98    constructor is a function that determines the decay of a chunk of the form
 99    $a^b$. The say function can have one or two parameters:
100
101    * If the say function accepts one parameter, the LookAndSay object will correspond to the decay $a^b\\to say(b)a$.
102    * If the say function accepts two parameters, the LookAndSay object will correspond to the decay $a^b\\to say(b, a)$.
103
104    When no parameter is passed to the constructor, the LookAndSay
105    object will correspond to standard base ten look and say sequences.
106
107    
108    ## Example Session: Default Constructor. 
109    The following example uses the default (standard) look and say sequences.
110    Note that the ratios of lengths are approaching Conway's constant.
111    ```python 
112    >>> ls = LookAndSay()  
113    >>> ls.generate_sequence('55555', 35)
114    >>> sequence = ls.get_sequence()
115    >>> first_terms = sequence[:10]
116    >>> 
117    >>> print('Sequence:', first_terms)
118    Sequence: ['55555', '55', '25', '1215', '11121115', '31123115', '132112132115', '11131221121113122115', '311311222112311311222115', '1321132132211213211321322115']
119    >>> 
120    >>> print('Ratios of lengths:', ls.get_length_ratios())
121    Ratios of lengths: [0.4, 1.0, 2.0, 2.0, 1.0, 1.5, 1.6666666666666667, 1.2, 1.1666666666666667, 1.5714285714285714, 1.1818181818181819, 1.1538461538461537, 1.4666666666666666, 1.2727272727272727, 1.25, 1.4, 1.3265306122448979, 1.2461538461538462, 1.3333333333333333, 1.3518518518518519, 1.226027397260274, 1.312849162011173, 1.3361702127659574, 1.2611464968152866, 1.3257575757575757, 1.318095238095238, 1.2919075144508672, 1.3053691275167785, 1.3161953727506426, 1.2936197916666667, 1.2989431303472572, 1.3142192948469587, 1.2951061320754718, 1.2997951286137037]
122    >>> 
123    >>> print('Just the last ratio:', ls.get_last_length_ratio())
124    Just the last ratio: 1.2997951286137037
125

186    Here is [Morrill's *Look Knave*](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/bulletin-of-the-australian-mathematical-society/article/abs/look-knave/BFC51822DED97095C96ABD2255AEDC2A):
187    ```python
188    >>> def knave_say(bit_count, bit):
189    ...     flip = {'0':'1', '1':'0'}
190    ...     return "{0:b}".format(bit_count) + flip[bit]
191    ... 
192    >>> look_knave = LookAndSay(knave_say)
193    >>> 
194    >>> look_knave.generate_sequence('0', 13)
195    >>> print(look_knave.get_sequence())
196    ['0', '11', '100', '10101', '1011101110', '10111101111011', '1011100011100011100', '1011110111110111110101', '1011100011101011101011101110', '10111101111101110111101110111101111011', '10111000111010111101110001111011100011100011100', '1011110111110111011100011110111100011110111110111110101', '1011100011101011110111101111000111000111100011101011101011101110']
197    >>> 
198    >>> look_knave.generate_sequence('1', 13)
199    >>> print(look_knave.get_sequence())
200    ['1', '10', '1011', '1011100', '1011110101', '1011100011101110', '10111101111101111011', '1011100011101011100011100', '1011110111110111011110111110101', '101110001110101111011100011101011101110', '10111101111101110111000111101111101110111101111011', '10111000111010111101111011110001110101111011100011100011100', '10111101111101110111000111000111000111110111011100011110111110111110101']
201
202    ```
203    """
204    def __init__(self, say = None):
205        super(LookAndSay, self).__init__()
206        self._is_Conway = False
207        if say == None:
208            say = (lambda n : str(n))
209            self._is_Conway = True
210        self.say = say
211        self.sequence = []
212
213    def _chunk_op(self, char_count, char):
214        """
215        Conversion of the say function to a two parameter function 
216        if the say function takes only one parameter; 
217        just a copy of the say function otherwise.
218        """
219        try:
220            return self.say(char_count, char)
221        except:
222            return self.say(char_count) + char
223
224    def get_sequence(self):
225        """Returns the look and say sequence as a list of strings"""
226        return self.sequence
227
228    def say_what_you_see(self, string):
229        """
230        The fundamental look and say operation that generates each 
231        term of a look and say sequence from its predecessor. For example, 
232        using the standard (default) LookAndSay object, 
233        ``say_what_you_see('1112222333')`` returns ``'314233'``.
234        """
235        if not string: return '' # handles empty string, which is falsy
236        letter = string[0]
237        result = ''
238        count = 0
239        for ch in string:
240            if ch == letter: 
241                count += 1
242            else:
243                result += self._chunk_op(count, letter)
244                count = 1
245                letter = ch 
246        result += self._chunk_op(count, letter)
247        return result
248     
249    def generate_sequence(self, seed, terms):
250        """
251        Generates the look and say sequence. The parameter ``seed`` is 
252        the initial term in the sequence, and ``terms`` is the 
253        number of terms generated.
254        """
255        if not seed: return None # handles empty seed, which is falsy
256        result = [seed]
257        for _ in range(terms-1):
258            result.append(self.say_what_you_see(result[-1]))
259        self.sequence = result
260
261    def get_length_ratios(self):
262        """
263        Returns a list of the ratios of lengths of 
264        successive terms in the look and say sequence.
265        """
266        terms = len(self.sequence)
267        assert terms > 1, 'Look and say sequence does not have enough terms to compute the ratio of lengths.'
268        return [len(self.sequence[i+1]) / len(self.sequence[i]) for i in range(terms - 1)]
269
270    def get_last_length_ratio(self):
271        """
272        Returns the ratio of the lengths of the last 
273        two terms of the look and say sequence
274        """
275        return self.get_length_ratios()[-1]

A class responsible for the fundamental say-what-you-see operation that generates a look and say sequence. The parameter say in the constructor is a function that determines the decay of a chunk of the form $a^b$. The say function can have one or two parameters:

  • If the say function accepts one parameter, the LookAndSay object will correspond to the decay $a^b\to say(b)a$.
  • If the say function accepts two parameters, the LookAndSay object will correspond to the decay $a^b\to say(b, a)$.

When no parameter is passed to the constructor, the LookAndSay object will correspond to standard base ten look and say sequences.

Example Session: Default Constructor.

The following example uses the default (standard) look and say sequences. Note that the ratios of lengths are approaching Conway's constant.

>>> ls = LookAndSay()  
>>> ls.generate_sequence('55555', 35)
>>> sequence = ls.get_sequence()
>>> first_terms = sequence[:10]
>>> 
>>> print('Sequence:', first_terms)
Sequence: ['55555', '55', '25', '1215', '11121115', '31123115', '132112132115', '11131221121113122115', '311311222112311311222115', '1321132132211213211321322115']
>>> 
>>> print('Ratios of lengths:', ls.get_length_ratios())
Ratios of lengths: [0.4, 1.0, 2.0, 2.0, 1.0, 1.5, 1.6666666666666667, 1.2, 1.1666666666666667, 1.5714285714285714, 1.1818181818181819, 1.1538461538461537, 1.4666666666666666, 1.2727272727272727, 1.25, 1.4, 1.3265306122448979, 1.2461538461538462, 1.3333333333333333, 1.3518518518518519, 1.226027397260274, 1.312849162011173, 1.3361702127659574, 1.2611464968152866, 1.3257575757575757, 1.318095238095238, 1.2919075144508672, 1.3053691275167785, 1.3161953727506426, 1.2936197916666667, 1.2989431303472572, 1.3142192948469587, 1.2951061320754718, 1.2997951286137037]
>>> 
>>> print('Just the last ratio:', ls.get_last_length_ratio())
Just the last ratio: 1.2997951286137037

Example Sessions: One parameter say functions

Here is an implementation of a Roman look and say:

>>> def roman_say(num):
...     assert num < 10, "This Roman can only count to 9."
...     roman = {1:'I', 2:'II', 3:'III', 4:'IV', 5:'V', 6:'VI', 7:'VII', 8:'VIII', 9:'IX'}
...     return roman[num]
... 
>>> roman_ls = LookAndSay(roman_say)
>>> 
>>> roman_ls.generate_sequence('I', 11)
>>> print(roman_ls.get_sequence())
['I', 'II', 'III', 'IIII', 'IVI', 'IIIVII', 'IIIIIVIII', 'VIIVIIII', 'IVIIIIVIVI', 'IIIVIVIIVIIIVII', 'IIIIIVIIIVIIIIVIIIIIVIII']
>>> 
>>> roman_ls.generate_sequence('V', 11)
>>> print(roman_ls.get_sequence())
['V', 'IV', 'IIIV', 'IIIIIV', 'VIIV', 'IVIIIIV', 'IIIVIVIIV', 'IIIIIVIIIVIIIIV', 'VIIVIIIIIVIVIIV', 'IVIIIIVVIIVIIIVIIIIV', 'IIIVIVIIIVIIIIVIIIIIVIVIIV']

Here is a standard binary look and say:

>>> def binary_say(num):
...     return "{0:b}".format(num)

>>> print(binary_ls.get_sequence())

Example Sessions: Two parameter say functions

Here is a look-and-say-again from the paper Stuttering Conway Sequences Are Still Conway Sequences by Brier et al. The say function for this example corresponds to the decay $a^b\to bbaa$.

>>> def say_again(char_count, char):
...     return 2 * str(char_count) + 2 * char
... 
>>> look_and_say_again = LookAndSay(say_again)
>>> 
>>> look_and_say_again.generate_sequence('1', 11)
>>> print(look_and_say_again.get_sequence())

281class Chemistry():
282    """
283    A class responsible for generating all the persistent elements 
284    appearing in look and say sequences, along with 
285    the chemical properties of those elements.
286
287    Parameters in the constructor are a LookAndSay object ``las`` and
288    a splitting function ``split``. The user is responsible
289    for verifying that the provided splitting function is valid for the given
290    LookAndSay object. The default splitting function corresponds to 
291    Conway's original Splitting Theorem.
